user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 21.17.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
Yes. OS_CHECK_APINAME(var_name) expands to OS_CHECK_STRING(var_name,OS_MAX_API_NAME,...). If OS_CHECK_STRING is implemented using unbounded string functions (e.g. strlen(var_name) or strncpy without a prior bounded-length check) then a caller-supplied var_name that is not null-terminated or points to a shorter object can cause the string routine to read beyond the bounds of the object referenced by var_name. For example, if OS_CHECK_STRING uses strlen(var_name) and the caller passes a non-null-terminated buffer, strlen will scan past the buffer end -> out-of-bounds access (MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 violation).
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified OS_CondVarCreate code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/763.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarCreate:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarCreate(osal_id_t *var_id, const char *var_name, uint32 options)
{
    int32                         return_code;
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    OS_condvar_internal_record_t *condvar;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(var_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(var_name);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        condvar = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_condvar_table, token);

        /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
        OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, condvar, obj_name, var_name);

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_CondVarCreate_Impl(&token, options);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, var_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified OS_CondVarCreate code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original OS_CondVarCreate with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as OS_CondVarCreate.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call OS_CondVarCreate to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of OS_CondVarCreate as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, OS_CondVarCreate will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of OS_CondVarCreate as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
